topics.title: Geometry - Shapes and Measurements
topics.description: Understanding 2D and 3D shapes, perimeter, area, and volume calculations

contents.title: Introduction to Geometry
contents.content:
Geometry is the branch of mathematics that deals with shapes, sizes, positions, and properties of space.

Basic Geometric Terms:

1. Point:
   â€¢ Exact location in space
   â€¢ No length, width, or height
   â€¢ Represented by a dot
   â€¢ Named with capital letters: A, B, C

2. Line:
   â€¢ Straight path extending infinitely in both directions
   â€¢ No endpoints
   â€¢ Named with two points: Line AB

3. Line Segment:
   â€¢ Part of a line with two endpoints
   â€¢ Has definite length
   â€¢ Example: Segment AB

4. Ray:
   â€¢ Part of a line with one endpoint
   â€¢ Extends infinitely in one direction
   â€¢ Example: Ray AB

5. Angle:
   â€¢ Formed by two rays with common endpoint
   â€¢ Measured in degrees (Â°)
   â€¢ Common endpoint called vertex

Types of Angles:
â€¢ Acute Angle: Less than 90Â°
â€¢ Right Angle: Exactly 90Â°
â€¢ Obtuse Angle: Between 90Â° and 180Â°
â€¢ Straight Angle: Exactly 180Â°
â€¢ Reflex Angle: Between 180Â° and 360Â°
â€¢ Complete Angle: Exactly 360Â°

contents.title: 2D Shapes - Triangles
contents.content:
Triangle: A polygon with three sides and three angles.

Properties:
â€¢ Sum of all angles = 180Â°
â€¢ Sum of any two sides > third side
â€¢ Three vertices, three sides, three angles

Types by Sides:
1. Equilateral Triangle:
   â€¢ All three sides equal
   â€¢ All angles = 60Â°
   â€¢ Most symmetric

2. Isosceles Triangle:
   â€¢ Two sides equal
   â€¢ Two angles equal
   â€¢ Base angles are equal

3. Scalene Triangle:
   â€¢ All sides different
   â€¢ All angles different
   â€¢ No symmetry

Types by Angles:
1. Acute Triangle:
   â€¢ All angles < 90Â°

2. Right Triangle:
   â€¢ One angle = 90Â°
   â€¢ Pythagoras theorem applies
   â€¢ Hypotenuse is longest side

3. Obtuse Triangle:
   â€¢ One angle > 90Â°

Formulas:
â€¢ Perimeter = Sum of all sides = a + b + c
â€¢ Area = 1/2 Ã— base Ã— height
â€¢ For right triangle: Area = 1/2 Ã— base Ã— perpendicular
â€¢ Pythagoras: aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ² (for right triangle)

contents.title: Triangle Problems
contents.content:
Example 1: Finding Missing Angle
In a triangle, two angles are 45Â° and 65Â°. Find the third angle.

Solution:
Sum of angles in triangle = 180Â°
Let third angle = x
45Â° + 65Â° + x = 180Â°
110Â° + x = 180Â°
x = 180Â° - 110Â°
x = 70Â°

Answer: Third angle = 70Â°

Example 2: Perimeter of Triangle
Sides of a triangle are 5 cm, 7 cm, and 9 cm. Find perimeter.

Solution:
Perimeter = Sum of all sides
= 5 + 7 + 9
= 21 cm

Answer: Perimeter = 21 cm

Example 3: Area of Triangle
Base = 12 cm, Height = 8 cm. Find area.

Solution:
Area = 1/2 Ã— base Ã— height
= 1/2 Ã— 12 Ã— 8
= 1/2 Ã— 96
= 48 cmÂ²

Answer: Area = 48 cmÂ²

Example 4: Pythagoras Theorem
In a right triangle, base = 3 cm, height = 4 cm. Find hypotenuse.

Solution:
Using Pythagoras theorem:
aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ²
3Â² + 4Â² = cÂ²
9 + 16 = cÂ²
25 = cÂ²
c = âˆš25
c = 5 cm

Answer: Hypotenuse = 5 cm

examples.title: Real-Life Application
examples.code:
Problem: A ladder 10 meters long leans against a wall. The foot of the ladder is 6 meters from the wall. How high up the wall does the ladder reach?

Solution:
This forms a right triangle:
Hypotenuse (ladder) = 10 m
Base (distance from wall) = 6 m
Height (up the wall) = ?

Using Pythagoras:
BaseÂ² + HeightÂ² = HypotenuseÂ²
6Â² + hÂ² = 10Â²
36 + hÂ² = 100
hÂ² = 100 - 36
hÂ² = 64
h = 8 m

Answer: Ladder reaches 8 meters up the wall.
examples.explanation: Pythagoras theorem is used in real-life for calculating distances, heights, and diagonal measurements.

contents.title: Quadrilaterals
contents.content:
Quadrilateral: A polygon with four sides, four angles, and four vertices.

Properties:
â€¢ Sum of all angles = 360Â°
â€¢ Four sides, four vertices

Types of Quadrilaterals:

1. Square:
   â€¢ All sides equal
   â€¢ All angles = 90Â°
   â€¢ Diagonals equal and bisect at 90Â°
   â€¢ Perimeter = 4 Ã— side
   â€¢ Area = side Ã— side = sideÂ²

2. Rectangle:
   â€¢ Opposite sides equal
   â€¢ All angles = 90Â°
   â€¢ Diagonals equal
   â€¢ Perimeter = 2(length + width)
   â€¢ Area = length Ã— width

3. Parallelogram:
   â€¢ Opposite sides equal and parallel
   â€¢ Opposite angles equal
   â€¢ Diagonals bisect each other
   â€¢ Perimeter = 2(a + b)
   â€¢ Area = base Ã— height

4. Rhombus:
   â€¢ All sides equal
   â€¢ Opposite angles equal
   â€¢ Diagonals bisect at 90Â°
   â€¢ Perimeter = 4 Ã— side
   â€¢ Area = 1/2 Ã— dâ‚ Ã— dâ‚‚ (d = diagonals)

5. Trapezium:
   â€¢ One pair of parallel sides
   â€¢ Area = 1/2 Ã— (sum of parallel sides) Ã— height

6. Kite:
   â€¢ Two pairs of adjacent sides equal
   â€¢ One diagonal bisects the other at 90Â°

contents.title: Quadrilateral Problems
contents.content:
Example 1: Square
Side of square = 8 cm. Find perimeter and area.

Solution:
Perimeter = 4 Ã— side
= 4 Ã— 8
= 32 cm

Area = sideÂ²
= 8Â²
= 64 cmÂ²

Answer: Perimeter = 32 cm, Area = 64 cmÂ²

Example 2: Rectangle
Length = 15 cm, Width = 8 cm. Find perimeter and area.

Solution:
Perimeter = 2(l + w)
= 2(15 + 8)
= 2 Ã— 23
= 46 cm

Area = l Ã— w
= 15 Ã— 8
= 120 cmÂ²

Answer: Perimeter = 46 cm, Area = 120 cmÂ²

Example 3: Rhombus
Diagonals are 12 cm and 16 cm. Find area.

Solution:
Area = 1/2 Ã— dâ‚ Ã— dâ‚‚
= 1/2 Ã— 12 Ã— 16
= 1/2 Ã— 192
= 96 cmÂ²

Answer: Area = 96 cmÂ²

Example 4: Trapezium
Parallel sides are 10 cm and 14 cm, height = 6 cm. Find area.

Solution:
Area = 1/2 Ã— (a + b) Ã— h
= 1/2 Ã— (10 + 14) Ã— 6
= 1/2 Ã— 24 Ã— 6
= 72 cmÂ²

Answer: Area = 72 cmÂ²

examples.title: Word Problem - Garden
examples.code:
Problem: A rectangular garden is 25 meters long and 15 meters wide. Find:
a) Perimeter (for fencing)
b) Area (for grass)

Solution:
a) Perimeter = 2(l + w)
= 2(25 + 15)
= 2 Ã— 40
= 80 meters

b) Area = l Ã— w
= 25 Ã— 15
= 375 square meters

Answer:
a) 80 meters of fencing needed
b) 375 sq meters of grass needed
examples.explanation: Perimeter is used for boundaries (fencing, framing). Area is used for covering surfaces (flooring, painting).

contents.title: Circles
contents.content:
Circle: A round shape where all points are equidistant from the center.

Parts of Circle:

â€¢ Diameter (d): Distance across circle through center

â€¢ Circumference: Perimeter of circle
â€¢ Chord: Line segment joining two points on circle
â€¢ Arc: Part of circumference
â€¢ Sector: Pie-shaped region

examples.title: Word Problem - Circular Park
examples.code:
Problem: A circular park has radius 35 meters. Find:

Solution:
